title: Vegas gangster Benny Binion's Texas gambling den is selling for $12 million
text:
Advertisement

The 1,369-acre compound located near Athens, Texas in rural Henderson County was used as a gambling spot for gangsters including Benny Binion (pictured)

An east Texas hideaway home with ties to one of the most feared interstate gamblers and mobsters of the mid 20th century has hit the real estate market for the first time since 1968.

The 1,369-acre Fincastle compound near the city of Athens, Texas, is on the market for $11.95 million.

The main house was built in the 1950s by Dallas gangster Ivy Miller - an associate of notorious crime boss Benny Binion.

Miller used the 1,369-acre compound located near Athens, Texas in rural Henderson County - an estimated 90 minute drive from Dallas - as a gambling spot for him, his convicted murderer commander, and their associates.

'It was built for the secret gambling society of Dallas, where they would do what guys on the underground do— where they had their rendezvous,' listing agent Bernard Uechtritz of Icon Global told real estate outlet Mansion Global.

Miller served as one of Binion's top lieutenants during the racketeer's rise to power in the Dallas area during the 1940s.

Binion left Dallas for Las Vegas in 1946. He went on to found the famed Horseshoe Casino on the Sin City strip as well as the card tournament known today as the World Series of Poker.

Today the asking price for the legendary Fincastle estate is $11.95 million

The home's historic gangster gambling den was once used by Miller, Binion, and their cohorts

The Fincastle estate served as a gambling spot for Miller, Binion, and their associates

But Miller stayed in the Lonestar State to run operations there amid a bloody turf war with fellow Texas gangsters that resulted in many unattributed deaths, according to a profile piece published in Texas Monthly two years after Binion died in 1989 at the age of 85.

The Fincastle property was sold to a private Dallas-based family following Miller's death in 1968, and this is the first time it has hit the market since.

The main house has been added to since, and now measures several thousand square feet.

The rural retreat the pair left behind is an outdoors lover's dream - with three enormous lakes stocked with fish.

There is also an array of wildlife in the forested grounds, including large herds of white tail deer, according to its listing page.

Rustic Adirondack-style architecture and vaulted ceilings accentuate the home, which also features an ornamental stone fireplace and wood paneling.

Rustic Adirondack-style architecture and vaulted ceilings accentuate the home, which also features an ornamental stone fireplace and wood paneling

A wooded area near one of the compounds lakes has a tree swing for kids and the young at heart

The rural retreat the gruesome twosome left behind is an outdoors lover's dream - with three enormous lakes stocked with fish and an array of wildlife, including large herds of white tail deer

The 1,369-acre Fincastle compound is located near Athens, Texas in rural Henderson County - an estimated 90 minute Drive from Dallas

Benny Binion, center, leaves a Las Vegas federal courtroom after an extradition hearing in 1952

The dwelling's wide-open spaces have a communal lodge feel with bedrooms sitting at each end of the house.

Perhaps most notable is the historic gangster gambling den once used by Miller, Binion, and their cohorts.

It sits in a scenic area with a panoramic view of Fincastle Lake.

Uechtritz said the hardest decision the home's potential new owner will have to make will be to keep the historic decor and style or renovate it to make it their own.

'If you have someone who’s really interested in having a talking piece, they may opt to save it,' he said.
description: The 1,369-acre Fincastle compound, near the city of Athens, Texas, is on the market for $11.95 million, and was once used by gangsters Ivy Miller and his notorious boss Benny Binion.
